entry.title: Enhanced Mapping of Advanced VariantConfiguration Characteristic Values to ProductionOrder Operation
entry.content:
Introduction

With the SAP Cloud ERP for Public Cloud 2502.4 release, a valuable new feature has been introduced, 'Enhanced Mapping of Advanced Variant Configuration Characteristic Values to Production Orders'. This enhancement allows you to map variant configuration characteristic values directly to custom fields within production routing operations. These custom fields can then be used as parameters in Work Centre formulas to dynamically calculate activities such as machine processing time, labour, and setup costs.

In this blog post, we'll explore how this feature can be applied in a real-world scenario to improve cost accuracy and operational efficiency in a manufacturing process.

Business Scenario

Imagine an automobile manufacturing company where the sit fitment time and cost vary depending on the number of seats to be installed in a custom-built caravan. In the custom-built caravan production process, the sit fitment time is calculated based on the number of seats selected by the customer during order configuration. In this case, the sit fitment time is expressed as machine time, calculated using a custom formula in the Work Centre.

Letâ€™s say the time factor is 1 for assembling 5 seats, which serves as the base configuration. We then maintain time factors of 3 for 6 seats and 5 for 7 seats to represent the proportionally higher effort and machine time required as the seat count increases, due to added installation work, alignment, and quality checks.

The table below illustrates this:

Seat Count (Z_SEAT_COUNT)

Time Factor (Z_SAFT)

Explanation

5

1

Base time unit

6

3

3Ã— time of 5-seat fitment

7

5

5Ã— time of 5-seat fitment

Consider the characteristic Z_SEAT_COUNT captures the number of seats selected. The system uses a dependency procedure (e.g., SEAT_ASSEMBLY) to calculate the machine time factor (Z_SAFT), which is then used to determine the overall operation time in routing.

This feature is especially valuable for industries that manufacture products with dynamic or customizable designsâ€”such as automotive, furniture, modular kitchens, pool tile manufacturing, or industrial machineryâ€”where production time and cost vary significantly based on configuration-specific attributes.

In the following section, weâ€™ll walk through how this use case can be implemented using the new feature in SAP Cloud ERP for Public Cloud.

Prerequisites

Before implementing this feature, ensure the following prerequisites are met:

  1. Activate the Feature
    Enable the feature "Map Object Dependency Value to Operation" (FTGL_PPH_MD_MAPOBJDPNVALS_2) via the Activate Features configuration activity in your system.

  1. Create a Custom Field
    Define a custom field under the business context Manufacturing: Bill of Operations Operation. This field will be used in the Work Centre formula to calculate activities like machine, setup or labour time and cost.
    For detailed steps on how to create a custom field and incorporate it into a Work Centre formula, refer to the link below:
    ğŸ‘‰https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/step-by-step-guide-to-setting-up-custom-fields-in-work-center-formula/ba-p/14123514
  2. Create a Super Routing with Object Dependency
    Set up a Super Routing for the configurable material and assign an Object Dependency of type 'Procedure' to the relevant operation.
    For guidance on how to create a routing for configurable materials, refer to the documentation below:
    ğŸ‘‰https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/f369b2eff700401494ba6e7c9a573288/d5ed07180f7a40189b043c8156157919.html?version=2502.500

Step-by-Step Execution:

1) Create and Verify Custom Field
Ensure that a custom field is created in the business context Manufacturing: Bill of Operations Operation. This field should be visible at the operation level in the routing.
In this example, weâ€™ve created a custom field called Seat Assembly Time Factor (YY1_SEAT_ASSEMBLY_TIME_PPO) to represent the offset value used for time and cost calculation.

2) Define Work Centre Formula
Create a Work Centre formula (e.g., Z_TIME) that uses a parameter (e.g., Z_SATF) linked to the custom field created above. This formula will be used to dynamically calculate activity times based on the selected configuration

3) Assign Formula to Work Centre Activities
Assign the custom formula (Z_TIME) to the relevant activity types (e.g., Setup, Machine, or Labour) in the Work Centre (SEATASMB) responsible for the seat assembly operation.    

4) Create Characteristic and Map to Custom Field
Define a variant configuration characteristic (e.g., Z_SATF) and map it to the custom field YY1_SEAT_ASSEMBLY_TIME_PPO. This enables the system to pass characteristic values to the routing operation dynamically.

5) Create Super Routing and Assign Procedure
Set up a Super Routing for the configurable material (e.g., a car model), and assign an Object Dependency of type â€˜Procedureâ€™ to the relevant operation (e.g., Seat Assembly).
In this example, the Seat Assembly Time Factor (Z_SATF) is determined based on the selected number of seats. The procedure is defined as below,

WorkCentre SEATASMB assigned to the operation 0025 â€“ Assemble Seat Units

Object dependency of type Procedure

Dependency Editor

6) Create Sales Order and Test Configuration
Once all the above steps are complete, create a Sales Order for the configurable material. On the Variant Configuration screen, select the desired number of seats.
Then, review the machine cost and overall calculated activity costs â€” they should adjust dynamically based on the selected characteristic value (i.e., the number of seats).

a) Select number of seats as â€˜5â€™ in the variant configuration screen

Cost of Goods Sold and Seat assembly machine processing cost for 5-seater.

b) Select number of seats as â€˜6â€™ in the variant configuration screen

Cost of Goods Sold and Seat assembly machine processing cost for 6-seater.

c) Select number of seats as â€˜7â€™ in the variant configuration screen

Cost of Goods Sold and Seat assembly machine processing cost for 5-seater.

Conclusion

The â€œEnhanced Mapping of Advanced Variant Configuration Characteristic Values to Production Ordersâ€ feature in SAP Cloud ERP for Public Cloud 2502.4 offers greater flexibility and accuracy in manufacturing configurable materials. By mapping configuration characteristics to custom fields in production operations and using them in Work Centre formulas, manufacturers can calculate activity times and costs dynamically based on real-time inputs. In the seat assembly example, processing time and cost adjust based on the number of seats selected, improving cost transparency and operational efficiency. This is especially valuable in make-to-order and engineer-to-order scenarios, where production effort varies with each configuration.

By leveraging it, businesses can better align operational planning with customer-specific configurationsâ€”driving both efficiency and customer satisfaction.

Happy Learning!!

entry.title: Custom Business Configurations (F4579): Controlling the visibility of BC Objects using authorization
entry.content:
Introduction

The Custom Business Configurations (CUBCO) app serves as an entry point to the Business Configuration Maintenance Object provided by custom applications or partners.
Depending on the respective role the user should only be able to edit certain business configurations.

This blog is relevant for

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition  
  • SAP BTP ABAP environment  

Further reading:

  • Related blog posts
  • Learn how you can use ABAP technology to develop innovative applications and business solutions across SAPâ€™s portfolio on SAP Learning Site.

Basic Concept

An OData V4 service is assigned to each business configuration object (SMBC). The corresponding service binding is based on a RAP BO.
The list of available business configuration objects in the CUBCO app is restricted to those where the user has the start authorization for the service binding (authorization object S_START,  see access control object I_SMBC_CONFIGURATION_TP).  The application-specific authorizations are not checked until an SMBC object has been selected. That is, authorization control implemented in the RAP BO. Normally, the authorization object S_TABU_NAM is used, but you can also use any other authorization object.

Therefore, you can create business roles in which only a subset of all business configuration objects can be used.

SAP BTP ABAP environment, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

IAM apps are the smallest building block for creating business roles. For a business configuration object, you assign the OData service binding and the application relevant authorization objects to it. You then create a business catalog to collect IAM apps and finally assign business catalogs to business roles.

Example:
You have four SMBC objects A, B, C, D in the system and a different OData service binding for each SMBC object. The authorization object S_TABU_NAM is used in all RAP BOs. You create four IAM apps A, B, C, D, each containing the OData service of a different SMBC object and the authorization object S_TABU_NAM. You create a business catalog BC1 that contains the IAM apps A, B, and a business catalog BC2 that contains the IAM apps B, C, D.

You assign a business role containing the business catalog BC1 to a user. This user can work with the SMBC objects A, B. The user cannot see or edit the SMBC objects C and D.
You assign a business role containing the business catalog BC2 to a user. This user can work with the SMBC objects B, C, D. The user cannot see or work with the SMBC object A.

SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition

IAM apps are not available. You add the application relevant authorization objects to the authorization default of the OData service assigned to the SMBC object. In the PFCG role you then add the authorization default.

Example:
You have four SMBC objects A, B, C, D in the system and a different OData service binding for each SMBC object. You assign a PFCG role containing the authorization default for the OData services of SMBC objects A, B to a user. This user can work with the SMBC objects A, B. The user cannot see or edit the SMBC objects C and D.

Note that roles that contain the Custom Business Configurations Fiori app do not automatically derive the required authorization for the SMBC objects. You need to add the authorization default of the OData service manually.

entry.title: Taking Control of Clean Core: When to Use Project Kernseife in addition to Standard SAP Tools
entry.content:
TL;DR

Measuring SAP Clean Core involves a choice:

  • As a RISE with SAP customer, you can benefit from the out-of-the-box standard approach with SAP Cloud ALM. The RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard provides you with a high-level standardized view with minimal effort.
  • Or you can choose an open-source, highly flexible, and customizable approach with Project Kernseife. You get custom classification to create actionable insights, but it requires ownership and additional effort.

This article will help you decide which path is right for your team's Clean Core journey.

How the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard measures Clean Core

SAP's answer on how to measure clean core is based on two standard tools: The ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC) (and its newly released checks as from SAP Note 3565942) and the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard in SAP Cloud ALM.

The process begins with the ATC, which analyzes your custom code against a well-defined set of rules. The key to this analysis is the classification of your custom extensions based on the official release status of the standard SAP objects they utilize. This release information is transparently published by SAP in the Cloudification Repository (Viewer).

As described in more detail in the Clean Core Extensibility Whitepaper (see chapter 3.3), the ATC assigns your extension a level based on the most critical SAP object it utilizes:

  • Level A - For extensions using only stable, released objects, ensuring maximum upgrade security.
  • Level B - For extensions whose most critical dependency is a classic API like a BAPI or classic technical frameworks.
  • Level C - For extensions touching any unreleased, internal SAP objects.
  • Level D - For extensions using objects that are explicitly not recommended.

The results of this structured analysis can then be uploaded to SAP Cloud ALM, populating the Clean Core Extensibility KPIs in the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard. Recently, the dashboard was enhanced with a display of the Clean Core  Levels. This gives organizations a high-level, standardized view of their extensibility landscape, which is perfect for assessing their current situation and tracking progress. For the near future (Q1/2026) it is moreover planned to offer a deep dive dashboard that provides further details about the results.

What is "Project Kernseife"?

Project Kernseife is an open-source custom ATC Check for ABAP systems that enables you to flexibly score the usage of SAP objects in your system, e.g. to score the technical debt regarding clean core based on a custom, adjustable classification. More details on the parts and approach can be found in the blog "Project Kernseife - improving the measurement of Clean Core in ABAP".

Why Project Kernseife and its custom classification can be a Game-Changer for Clean Core Governance

Advantage 1: Fine-Tune SAP's Rules & Reduce "False Positives"

While SAP delivers thousands of released and classic APIs, it might still be not the perfect fit for your individual project and scope. Kernseife allows you to customly classify objects as "acceptable for your project", dramatically reducing noise and the need for mass ATC exemptions. Let's look into two different scenarios, to show you the benefits of custom classification:

Example 1: Stricter governance for direct table read

Within the standard classification, a direct read with a SELECT from any SAP table is considered as "Level C", which leads to warnings in ABAP Test Cockpit. In your project, you want to enforce the usage of ABAP cloud, you maybe have (see next point) identified many successor objects (custom and standard) and want to push developers to the successors objects (e.g., famous I_Product instead of MARA) by showing these as an error.
Remark: In standard ATC, you can adjust the priority of a check message in general (for example "Reading from DDIC database tables or DDIC table views is not recommended (successor available)", but not based on specific SAP objects you refer to.

Example 2: Need for usage of "internal object"

Now let's imagine you are working in a "clean core" project, but you need to extend processes around the Outbound Delivery Orders in EWM. After talking to experts, finding blog posts and even an "official" SAP Note, you identified the right interface: /SCWM/IF_API_WHR_OUTBOUND. Unfortunately, this is not yet listed as released or classic API. This would result in "warnings" in ATC and a classification as Level C ("Internal Objects" are used), although you did the best you can do. With Kernseife, you can now mark this SAP object as "recommended", which results in only "information" messages in ATC and leads to a "Level B" assessment of the custom code object / extension.

Based on these two examples, you can see: this is the power of a custom classification. You can overrule the SAP standard, be it because of timing (as you need the announced adjustments from the blog IMMEDIATELY) or scope (because SAP might not generally classify everything that you identify as "acceptable for your project" as "Classic API").

The possibility to "accept" usage of certain SAP objects will increase your governance quality, as your exemption approvers will not be flooded with hundreds of "false" exemption requests for objects that you generally accept in your project.

Advantage 2: Define and Enforce Custom Successors

While SAP is already delivering hundreds of the most important successor classifications (famous MARA -> I_Product), there might still be potential to guide your developers more precisely. Project Kernseife allows you to maintain a successor object in your classification, that will also be visible in the result of your ATC check - this makes it actionable for your developer!

 

Example 1: "Improve" Standard Successors

There are some more tables in the system, that have no successor mentioned officially, but where you can find (released!) CDS views as an alternative. To not flood you with details here, I simply refer to another blog based on the idea of @AndreasGraeber. But also for Function Modules or classes , there might be clear successors (e.g. not all READ_<table> might be having the successor information. There might be a lot of areas, where you want to decide in your project "don't use this, but use that!"

Example 2: Enforce and centralize Wrappers / custom successors

What happens if you create a wrapper for a standard SAP object, but your colleagues are not aware of it? They might re-create the same wrapper. With the possibility to also add Custom Objects (e.g. Z_WRAPPER_ABC) as a successor, you can also push your developers to harmonize the usage of wrappers.

Advantage 3: Enhance Dashboards for Measurement and Governance with consistent transparency

In several projects, we have already seen custom dashboards to track the current state of clean core. With the combination of the level concept and the "Technical Debt Score", you can assess systems and drill down into packages or even single objects.

Project Kernseife offers you direct access (e.g. with CDS-View ZKNSF_I_SCORING) to the data from ATC check runs to build these dashboards. You can use the Kernseife BTP Application to analyze your score - or create your own dashboard, for example with SAP Analytics Cloud, reflecting your custom rules to assign custom objects to business units (e.g. ZBR* is always Brasil).

The scoring is based on your configuration in the Kernseife classification, which allows you to own the definition of your clean core levels and deviate from SAP's standard definition - by this you own the definition of your clean core levels! To stick with the examples above, the usage of /SCWM/IF_API_WHR_OUTBOUND will impact your score in a limited way.

Advantage 4: Prioritize Your Cleanup Efforts with a "Potential Score"

After an analysis, you often face a daunting list of findings. The biggest challenge isnâ€™t just identifying the issues, but knowing where to start the cleanup. This is where Kernseife's scoring mechanism becomes a powerful prioritization engine by providing two key metrics for each finding: a Score and a Potential Score.

  • The Score reflects the technical debt of the object as it exists today, based on your custom rules.
  • The Potential Score shows what the score would be if the developer refactored the code to use the defined successor.

Let's use our familiar example:

  • Your classification assigns a high "Technical Debt" Score of 10 for a direct SELECT on table MARA.
  • The officially released successor, I_Product, has a "clean" score of 0. Therefore, the finding's Potential Score is 0.

This creates a clear, quantifiable "improvement gap." An object with a Score of 10 and a Potential Score of 0 is a high-impact cleanup opportunity. In contrast, a finding with a Score of 2 and no defined successor (meaning its Potential Score is also 2) is a lower priority for immediate refactoring.

By sorting your findings based on the largest gap between the Score and Potential Score, you can instantly identify the "low-hanging fruits" and the refactoring tasks with the biggest impact. Let's be clear, this is just one piece of information, and maybe you shouldn't have any custom code in this area based on a process analysis, but I still believe it is important to have data to drive your decisions - and Project Kernseife offers you data for the technical insights.

Making the Right Choice: A Balanced Look at Both Approaches

Key Reasons to Adopt Project Kernseife

The main reason to use a Project Kernseife is typically the power of the custom classification (as the last chapter pointed out). You can adjust the classification of SAP objects based on your project reality and support your clean core journey with tailored data.

In addition, there might be a temporary, tactical benefit: As of today, Kernseife's dashboards can fill a gap until SAP's "Extensibility Deep Dive" dashboard is generally available. 

Important Considerations: When the Standard Approach is a Better Fit

At the same time, I want to be very clear: Project Kernseife is not needed in every company and project.

  • 1. The Need for Standard Alignment: If your primary goal is to align perfectly with SAP's out-of-the-box reporting and dashboards without deviation, the standard approach is more appropriate.
  • 2. The Responsibility of Power: Custom classification is powerful, but it requires ownership. Someone must define, document, and maintain these custom rules. This is an ongoing responsibility (and effort!), which you can spare yourself when you go with the standard solution, i.e. RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard.
  • 3. Implementation and Maintenance Overhead: While straightforward for experienced teams, implementing and maintaining any non-standard solution requires effort that must be planned for. It is ironically against the clean core imperative of leveraging "standard"!
  • 4. Unified Classification enables comparibility: Standardized classification leads to a comparability between different systems (e.g., you compare your central finance system with a peer system regarding the clean core level share), as the classification is the same for all systems.

Conclusion: Do you need to Take Control of Your Clean Core Strategy?

Project Kernseife is not for everyone. It is for organizations that find the standard clean core measurement too rigid and are ready to invest the effort to build a more nuanced, context-aware governance model. If you have the capacity and the architectural vision, it can transform your clean core initiative from a technical cleanup exercise into a strategic management of your system's extensibility.

Interested in more? Check out Project Kernseife: our open-source project where you can join the community, contribute, and support us with a GitHub star in the repository!

entry.title: Cloud BAdI to Influence Sales Document Copy Control
entry.content:
Cloud BAdIs For Sales Document Copy Control

As I explained in blog Sales Document BAdI Overview, there are following Cloud BAdIs defined to provide more flexibility of control the copying process from a reference document to a sales document. 

  • Copying Requirements for Sales Documents (from Sales Documents) - SD_SLS_COPY_RQMT_HEAD_SLS 
  • Copying Requirements for Sales Document Items (from Sales Documents) - SD_SLS_COPY_RQMT_ITEM_SLS 
  • Copying Requirements for Sales Documents (from Billing Documents) - SD_SLS_COPY_RQMT_HEAD_BIL
  • Copying Requirements for Sales Document Items (from Billing Documents) - SD_SLS_COPY_RQMT_ITEM_BIL
  • Data Transfer for Sales Document Headers - SD_SLS_DATA_TRANSFER_HEAD
  • Data Transfer for Sales Document Items - SD_SLS_DATA_TRANSFER_ITEM

These BAdI implementations can be assigned into sales document copy control  SSCUIs as special routines, similar to what could be done in VOFM transactions in SAP ECC era. 

According to BAdI definition, these BAdIs support "multiple implementation". It means you can create multiple BAdI implementations and then assign them into different copy control scenarios. 

Normally, the "COPY_RQMT" BAdIs are used to check whether the reference document can be copied to a target document. When business criteria is not met via BAdI implementation, the copy process will be cancelled. The "DATA_TRANSFER" BAdIs are processed after the "COPY_RQMT" BAdI is passed. In "DATA_TRANSFER" BAdI implementation, it is possible to control the field mapping between source document and the target document. 

BAdI Parameters

There are following typical parameters in "COPY_RQMT" BAdIs:

Parameter NameDescriptionParameter TypePurpose
SALESDOCUMENTSales document headerImportingContains sales document header data that customer can use to decide if copy control is relevant
SALESDOCUMENTITEMSales document itemImportingContains sales document item data that customer can use to decide if copy control is relevant
MESSAGESMessages Changing Customer can raise messages when applicable 
SALESDOCUMENT_COPYCANCELCancel header copy controlChangingThis is the control field that customer can decide whether to cancel the copy process

There are following typical parameters in "DATA_TRANSFER" BAdIs:

Parameter NameDescriptionParameter TypePurpose
SALESDOCUMENT_INSales document headerImportingContains sales document header data that customer can use to decide if copy control is relevant
SALESDOCUMENTITEM_INSales document itemImportingContains sales document item data that customer can use to decide if copy control is relevant
MESSAGESMessages Changing Customer can raise messages when applicable 
SALESDOCUMENT_OUTSales document changeable fieldsChangingThis structure contains all changeable fields on sales document header level that could be copied to the target document
SALESDOCUMENTITEM_OUTSales document item changeable fieldsChanginghis structure contains all changeable fields on sales document item level that could be copied to the target document

Not all standard fields in sales document header and sales document item are changeable in "DATA_TRANSFER" BAdIs. Until release CE2602, following sales document header fields are changeable in BAdI SD_SLS_DATA_TRANSFER_HEAD:

  • Purchase Order By Customer
  • Customer Purchase Order Date
  • Shipping Condition
  • SD Document Reason
  • Customer Purchase Order Type
  • Correspondence External Reference 

Following sales document item fields are changeable in BAdI SD_SLS_DATA_TRANSFER_ITEM:

  • Purchase Order By Customer 
  • Sales Product Hierarchy Node Origin
  • Delivery Date Quantity is Fixed
  • Customer Purchase Order Type
  • Correspondence External Reference

The custom fields on sales document header and item level are also changeable fields in "DATA_TRANSFER" BAdIs. 

Business Example 

Supplier company XYZ always negotiates with buyers via sales quotation. Once sales quotation is approved, sales orders can be created by referring to a sales quotation. Company XYZ doesn't want to create sales orders from a sales quotation if the sales quotation is close to expiration, e.g. a sales quotation will be expired in 3 days. 

The supply company XYZ has a special sales process called "Export Order". The "Export Order" is always created by reference to a sales quotation. The supply company XYZ wants to utilize the standard field "Customer Purchase Order Type" to differentiate the "Export Order" from the normal sales orders. 

Solution via Extensibility

The copy control BAdIs can be used to fulfill above requirements from supply company XYZ. The BAdI SD_SLS_COPY_RQMT_HEAD_SLS shall be implemented to check if the sales quotation is expired in 3 days and stop the copying process. The BAdI SD_SLS_DATA_TRANSFER_HEAD shall be implemented to set the "Customer Purchase Order Type" when a sales order is created from a sales quotation. 

Implement BAdI to Cancel Copy When Sales Quotation is Expired Soon

Go to app "Custom Logic" to create a new BAdI implementation for BAdI "SD_SLS_COPY_RQMT_HEAD_SLS".

Adding the filter "ENHANCEMENT_ID = QUOTE" as this BAdI allows multiple implementations. The enhancement ID can be used to identify the BAdI to be used in certain copy control entries. 

Create the BAdI implementation, and then define the custom logic.

* This BAdI checks the quotation validity period aginst to current order creation date.
* If the sales quotation is closed to experiation date, e.g. expire within 3 days,
* The sales order creation from sales quotation shall be stopped.
    if salesdocument-sddocumentcategory = 'B' and salesdocument-SALESORGANIZATION = '1710'.
        select * into table @DATA(lt_header) from i_salesquotation where salesquotation = @salesdocument-salesdocument.
        read table lt_header into data(ls_header) index 1.
        if sy-subrc = 0.
            salesdocument_copycancel = abap_false.
            data(ls_date) = cl_abap_context_info=>get_system_date( ). "get current date
            "make sure the sales quotation is still valid on current date.
            if ls_date >= ls_header-BindingPeriodValidityStartDate and ls_date <= ls_header-BindingPeriodValidityEndDate.
                data(ls_offset) = ls_header-BindingPeriodValidityEndDate - ls_date.
                if ls_offset < 3.
                    salesdocument_copycancel = abap_true.
                    "raise error message
                    data ls_msg like line of messages.
                    ls_msg-messagetype = 'E'.
                    ls_msg-messagetext = 'The sales quotation will be expired in ' && ls_offset && ' days, copied is not possible.'.
                    append ls_msg to messages.
                endif.
            else.
                salesdocument_copycancel = abap_true.
            endif.
        endif.
    endif.

Save and publish the BAdI logic. 

Open the app "Manage Your Solution" and open the SSCUI 103089 to define copy control routines. 

Create a new enhancement routine for BAdI "SD_SLS_COPY_RQMT_HEAD_SLS".

Go to detail node to assign enhancement ID.

Save the configuration. 

Go to SSCUI 102905 to assign this routine into copy control setting from sales quotation to sales order.

Assign the copy control requirement routine.

Test the behavior of creating sales orders from the sales quotation which is going to be expired in 3 days. 

There is a sales quotation valid from Nov 1st to Nov 12th. 

 

Create a sales order with reference to this sales quotation. 

After press button "Continue", error message is raised based on BAdI implementation logic. 

The copy control requirement BAdI can be used to stop copying process when certain business rules are not met. 

Implement BAdI to Determine Purchase Order Type in Sales Order

In order to fulfill the requirement to determine purchase order type when sales orders are created from a sales quotation, the BAdI "SD_SLS_DATA_TRANSFER_HEAD" can be implemented to set purchase order type. 

Firstly, go to SSCUI 103394 to define new purchase order type for "Export Order".

Define a new purchase order type "EXPO" for "Export Order".

Save the entry.

Go to app "Custom Logic" to create a new BAdI implementation for BAdI "SD_SLS_DATA_TRANSFER_HEAD".

In the BAdI implementation, add following custom logic to set customer purchase order type.

*   This method can be used to enhance the SAP standard copy control
*   from sales document to sales document and from billing document to sales document.

*   First of all assign existing field values to output parameter:
    move-corresponding salesdocument_in to salesdocument_out.

    if salesdocument_in-referencesddocumentcategory = 'B'.
        salesdocument_out-customerpurchaseordertype = 'EXPO'.
    endif.

Publish the BAdI implementation. 

Go to SSCUI 103089 to define new routine for above copy control BAdI implementation.

In the detail node, assign enhancement ID to this routine.

Then go to SSCUI 102905 to assign this routine 3000093 to the copy control entry. 

Save the configuration. 

There is a sales quotation which is valid until end of 2025.

Create a sales order with reference to this sales quotation.

After click "Continue" button, system navigates to the sales order creation page.

The purchase order type "EXPO" is defaulted based on custom logic in BAdI implementation. 

Moving Forward

The copy control BAdIs provide flexibility to influence sales document copying processes. They can control whether creating from reference is relevant or how fields are mapped from the source document to the target document.

However, not all sales document data is exposed as parameter in those BAdIs, and not all standard fields are changeable during the copying process. We will continue to invest in this direction to bring more flexibility to the copying process.

On the other hand, we also expect customers can raise requirement if any field is missing during copying. Please feel free to submit your requirement through the Customer Influence Portal, see detail in SAP note 2963059. Stay tuned for new features planned in our roadmap.

entry.title: Using Custom Logic in SAP S/4HANA Cloud to restrict multiple parkings of supplier invoices
entry.content:
Problem Background:

A customer has requested a requirement to restrict the repeated parking of goods receipt reference documents and reference document items corresponding to purchase orders that have already been parked and posted. If a purchase order has already completed goods receipt, reference document, and invoice posting, it should no longer be possible to park an invoice for this purchase order.

Solution:

Attempt to meet the requirement through custom logic using a BAdI.

Analysis Steps:

1. We have previously assisted customers with invoicing requirements, and the business enhancement points we need to use are the same. You can refer to these two blogs: Using Custom Logic in SAP S/4HANA Cloud to check if the payment terms of pre made invoices are consistent with those in supplier master data | SAP Blogs and Using Custom Logic in SAP S/4HANA Cloud to restrict invoicing of purchase orders with incomplete receipts | SAP Blogs .

First, we need to add an enhancement implementation in the application - Custom Logic of SAP S/4HANA Cloud system. According to the business scenario, select the business context Procurement: Supplier Invoice and business add-in description Check Invoice Data, and fill in the implementation description and implementation identifier.

2. After adding the enhancement implementation in Custom Logic, we need to find the CDS Views that can provide the business requirement fields. After testing, for the same PO + ITEM + goods receipt, if it has already been posted, the same goods receipt document cannot be selected again for repeated parking. Therefore, the fields I use as validation conditions here are PO and ITEM numbers. At the same time, since we need to check whether this PO and ITEM have already been posted, we need to use SUPPLIERINVOICESTATUS = '5' in I_SupplierInvoiceAPI01. However, this CDS View does not have the PO and ITEM fields, so we need to use I_SuplrInvcItemPurOrdRefAPI01. In the sample code below, I used a custom CDS View. You can create a custom CDS View YY1_I_SUPPLIERINVOICEAPI01 in your own system based on I_SupplierInvoiceAPI01, select the corresponding fields, and make adjustments.

At the same time, as I mentioned in my previous articles, in the sample code provided by the BAdI, we can find statements that can restrict the behavior that triggers the BAdI. According to our needs, we need to add the following statement to restrict the BAdI to only trigger during invoice parking, without affecting other processes:

Park: if_ex_mrm_check_invoice_cloud=>c_Action_Park

3. Based on the above analysis, implement the BAdI. The specific code is as follows.

loop at ITEMSWITHPOREFERENCE REFERENCE INTO DATA(Supinvoice_item).
if action = if_ex_mrm_check_invoice_cloud=>c_Action_Hold.
    select single 
    from YY1_I_SUPPLIERINVOICEAPI01 with privileged access
    where PURCHASEORDER = @Supinvoice_item->PURCHASEORDER and PURCHASEORDERITEM = @Supinvoice_item->PURCHASEORDERITEM
    and SUPPLIERINVOICESTATUS = '5'
    into (Is_Supinvoice_status) .
    if Is_Supinvoice_status = abap_true.
      append value #( messagetype = 'E' messageid = 'MRM_BADI_CLOUD' messagenumber = '001' messagevariable1 = 'æš‚å­˜çš„å‘ç¥¨æœ‰é‡å¤é¡¹ç›®ã€‚' ) to messages.
    endif.
endif.
endloop.

Conclusion:

By reading this article and several previous blogs on similar scenarios, I hope you now understand how to use custom logic to apply certain restrictions when creating preliminary invoices for purchase orders.
You can find more information about SAP S/4HANA Cloud procurement-related issues at the following link: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Sourcing and Procurement - SAP Community

You can also read more blogs about SAP S/4HANA Cloud procurement at the following link: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Sourcing and Procurement - SAP Community

entry.title: Generating OData Service Artifacts from Multiple CDS Views/Tables
entry.content:
ğŸ› ï¸ Step 1: Initialize the Service Generator

Start the Service Generator tool (often accessed via ADT or a relevant Fiori tool). You will typically begin by defining the main service configuration.

 

 

ğŸ”— Step 2: Define Business Object Entities

The key to multi-entity services is correctly defining all entities and their relationships.

A. Define the Parent Entity (Header)

  1. Add Entity: Start by adding the primary, or "Header," entity. In your case, this is R_S2P_VendMGNT.

    • Entity Alias: R_S2P_VendMGNT

    • Parent Name: Not applicable (as this is the top-level entity)

    • Fields: Define the necessary fields, such as VendorLegalName1, ensuring correct data types and lengths (e.g., Char, length 10).

    • You dont have to pass the key field, it will automatically generate to SAP UUID.

 

B. Define the Child Entity (Item)

  1. Add Entity: Add the secondary, or "Item," entity, which represents the line items. In your scenario, this is R_S2P_VMITem.

  2. Establish Relationship: This entity must be defined as a child of the header entity to enable navigation properties in the final OData service.

    • Entity Alias: R_S2P_VMITem

    • Parent Name: R_S2P_VendMGNT (The header entity)

    • Cardinality: "To Many" - This is crucial as one vendor (header) can have multiple line items (items).

  3. Fields: Define the item-specific fields (your image shows fields being added to R_S2P_VMITem as well).

 

âš™ï¸ Step 3: Review and Generate Artifacts

After defining both entities and their relationship, you can proceed to the generation step.

  1. Review Artifacts: The generator will prepare a list of ABAP Repository Objects to be created. This list confirms the successful configuration of the multi-entity service.

    The generated artifacts will include:

    • Service Definition (ZUI_R_S2P_VENDMGNT...ğŸ˜ Defines the entire OData service structure and exposes the entities.

    • Service Binding (ZUI_R_S2P_VENDMGNT...ğŸ˜ Provides a deployable endpoint for the OData service.

    • SAP Object Node Types (ZR_S2P_VENDMGNTğŸ˜ Defines the underlying object structure for each entity.

    • Data Definitions (D ZC_R_S2P...ğŸ˜ Defines the core ABAP structures.

    • Business Object Projection Entities: Maps the CDS entities to the Business Object layer.

  2. Generate: Click Finish to generate these artifacts.

 

ğŸ‰ Conclusion

By defining a hierarchical structure where the item entity is a child of the header entity with "To Many" cardinality, you successfully generate all required ABAP artifacts for a robust OData service that handles complex data from multiple source tables/CDS views. This service can now be consumed by Fiori applications to retrieve both header and line item data efficiently.

entry.title: Entendiendo la Extensibilidad en SAP Cloud ERP: Parte 3
entry.content:
Como vimos en los primeros dos blogs Parte 1 y Parte 2, extender SAP Cloud ERP (o comÃºnmente llamado SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition), es muy importante para adaptarse a la necesidad especÃ­fica de cada uno de tus clientes.

SAP Cloud ERP puede extenderse dentro de si misma, pero en esta parte final, abordaremos una de las formas Ã³ptimas de escalar tu soluciÃ³n y es, mediante el uso de la SAP Business Technology Platform o SAP BTP, mediante el diseÃ±o de aplicaciones Multi-tenant y multi-backend, para esto tenemos varios ejemplos dentro de los recursos oficiales de SAP, pero quiero mostrarles el que para mÃ­, es el mÃ¡s relevante para quienes desean comenzar en SAP Cloud ERP y tienen ya prÃ¡cticas en otro de nuestros productos, como SAP Business One o SAP Business ByDesign.

 

 

 

Proceso de desarrollo para un cliente a mÃºltiples tenants y diferentes Back-ends

Empecemos anÃ¡lizando lo siguiente: en tu empresa tienen una necesidad clara y deciden desarrollar una aplicaciÃ³n especÃ­fica para un cliente, para ello puedes crearla directamente In-App, usando por ejemplo Key-user o Developer Extensibility en Cloud ERP.

Como segundo anÃ¡lisis, quiero que revisemos lo que pasa, si te das cuenta que esa necesidad es la misma para otros usuarios, el camino entonces, es pensar en una soluciÃ³n multi-tenant, que de hecho puede ser desarrollada dentro de SAP Cloud ERP, usando por ejemplo la Multi-off Delivery o la Scalable Delivery.

Ahora como tercer anÃ¡lisis, Â¿quÃ© pasa si te das cuenta que esa aplicaciÃ³n no solo es Ãºtil para clientes de SAP Cloud ERP?, sino que tienes clientes de SAP Business One, SAP Business ByDesign, o incluso deseas poner la aplicaciÃ³n como standalone solution y permitir el acceso a clientes que no cuentan con una de nuestras ERPs. AllÃ­ se hace muy relevante escalar nuestra aplicaciÃ³n y usar la SAP BTP como centro de desarrollo y despliegue, nos referimos entonces a una aplicaciÃ³n Multi-tenant y Multi-backend o de ERP agnÃ³stico.

 

 

Modelos Operacionales

 

Como partner puedes tener diferentes modelos operacionales, uno de ellos es el modelo â€œCustomer Managedâ€ donde los clientes gestionan directamente la implementaciÃ³n y el mantenimiento de las soluciones, con el apoyo tÃ©cnico y consultoria del Partner.

Otro modelo es el â€œPartner SaaS Solutionsâ€, donde el Partner desarrolla y gestiona aplicaciones de software como servicio (SaaS) en la nube, utilizando la plataforma SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). Este modelo permite a los Partners ofrecer soluciones escalables y compatibles con las actualizaciones de SAP ERP, proporcionando a los clientes acceso a aplicaciones avanzadas y servicios como inteligencia artificial y machine Learning.

 

 

Partner Reference App: el caso de uso

 

La BTP Partner Reference App es un modelo, que te permite crear aplicaciones directamente en la SAP BTP, diseÃ±adas para ser compatibles con las actualizaciones de SAP Cloud ERP, lo cual deja como resultado: fÃ¡cil integraciÃ³n y mantenimiento de la misma. Incluye ventajas de compatibilidad y eficiencia. El link general de esta aplicaciÃ³n se encuentra publicado en nuestro GitHub  (BTP Partner Reference App).

La BTP Partner Reference app, sigue el modelo de soluciones de Software como Servicio para nuestros Partners. Al estar alojada en la SAP BTP estÃ¡ clasificada como una Side-by-side Extension, este tipo de aplicaciones son operadas desde esta plataforma y cuentan con ciclo de vida propio, independiente del ERP que se use.

Esta aplicaciÃ³n es un imaginario de un Poetry Slam, donde el usuario debe imaginar que es un manager de eventos, quien organiza eventos de poesÃ­a, y usa la aplicaciÃ³n para planear y ejecutar los eventos, analizar los costos, comprar equipo, publicar los eventos, manejar las reservas, los visitantes y artistas.

 

Este modelo, sigue los estÃ¡ndares SAP, con un modelo centralizado de identidad y autenticaciÃ³n, un Launchpad comÃºn, navegaciÃ³n entre aplicaciones y una integraciÃ³n back-end segura. Tienes dos formas de acceder a esta aplicaciÃ³n y probarla por ti mismo: la primera es ir directamente y clonar el repositorio de Github, o seguir paso a paso desde el desarrollo inicial hasta el modelo final. Below is an overview of the planned blog series â€“ each post focusing on a specific integration topic. Once published, the titles will be linked for direct access:

Integrating SAP EHS in the Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side â€“ Guidebook

Part 1: Introduction & OverviewLink
Part 2: Integration of Employees from SAP SuccessFactorsLink
Part 3: Integration of Business Partners & Material from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG)Link
Part 4: Integration of Functional Locations & Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise SystemLink

1. Introduction: Why Extensibility Matters in EHS Implementations

Implementing SAP Environment, Health & Safety (EHS) in the Public Cloud provides customers with a powerful set of standard capabilities across EHS functionality such as Incident Management, Risk Management, or Emissions Management. However, real-life EHS processes often include country-specific regulations, industry-dependent reporting obligations, and customer-individual workflows that cannot always be covered by the standard product alone. This is where extensibility becomes a critical success factor.

From our project experience, we see that nearly every EHS implementation requires selected adaptations â€“ whether to incorporate local legal requirements, enrich analytics, adjust incident forms, or create custom validations. With SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and SAP EHS, such enhancements must follow SAPâ€™s clean-core principles, meaning they must be implemented using the officially supported extensibility technologies.

This blog post provides a clear, practical overview of the extensibility options available for SAP EHS in the Public Cloud and demonstrates how they can be applied to real-world scenarios.

1.1 What You Can Expect from This Blog Post

In this part, we outline the extensibility landscape for EHS Public Cloud and guide you through:

  • Which extensibility options exist in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • How they apply specifically to EHS use cases
  • Which BAdIs are available and when to use them
  • Concrete examples for extensibility
  • Best practices based on our project experience

The aim is to give implementation teams a practical understanding of how to adapt the system without breaking the clean core, ensuring long-term upgradeability and compliance.

1.2 Why Extensibility is Especially Important for EHS

From our project experience, EHS is one of the most extensibility-driven domains in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud because:

  • Regulations differ significantly by country (e.g. OSHA, EU directives, etc.)
  • Incident reports must reflect local legal requirements
  • Customers require tailored analytics and KPIs
  • Integration with external safety systems is common
  • Forms and regulatory outputs often need custom structures

EHS processes must adapt to organizational legal, and operational needs. Extensibility in Public Cloud ensures this adaptability without compromising SAPâ€™s clean-core principles.

 

2. Extensibility Options in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provides a comprehensive extensibility portfolio designed to support innovation without compromising the stability of the core system. These capabilities range from low-code configuration tools for business users to pro-code development environments for technical teams. Understanding these options is essential for designing scalable, future-proof EHS solutions â€“ especially in Public Cloud environments where clean-core principles are mandatory.

Extensibility Portfolio for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Own illustration based on SAP source: https://www.sap.com/documents/2018/05/606d1ee8-037d-0010-87a3-c30de2ffd8ff.html)

2.1 Low-Code vs. Pro-Code Extensibility

The extensibility portfolio is structured along two axes:

  • Low-Code: Target at key user and functional experts who need to quickly adapt user interfaces, create fields, or adjust logic without deep technical development.
  • Pro-Code: Designed for professional developers who require advanced capabilities through the ABAP Cloud development model or SAP BTP services.

These options are distributed across two major extensibility categories: On-Stack Extensibility (In-App) & Side-by-Side Extensibility.

2.2 On-Stack Extensibility (In-App)

Executed directly inside SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, following the clean-core principles enforced by SAP.

Key User & Developer Extensibility

2.2.1 Key User Extensibility (Low-Code)

Accessible directly via the SAP Fiori Launchpad, key user extensibility enables business focused adjustments such as:

  • UI adaptation mode: Modify screen layouts, hide/show fields, rearrange sections.
  • Custom fields: Create and publish custom fields that automatically extend UI, APIs, CDS views, and reports.
  • Custom logic (using BAdIs or BDEF extensions): Implement small logic enhancements using predefined extensions points.
  • Custom business objects: Model simple new business objects without coding.
  • Custom CDS views & OData services: Build analytical and integration-ready views with drag-and-drop tooling.
  • Analytical queries and applications: Extend reporting and KPIs in SAP Fiori or SAP Analytics Cloud.

Key User Extensibility is ideal for EHS teams that need to adapt processes quickly, e.g. adding a regulatory field in Incident Management or creating country-specific reporting structures.

2.2.2 Developer Extensibility (Pro-Code)

Developer Extensibility is performed using ABAP Cloud in Eclipse via ABAP Development Tools (ADT), enabling professional developers to build upgrade-safe extensions inside the SAP S/4HANA Cloud stack.

Typical capabilities include:

  • UI adaptation projects via SAP Business Application Studio
  • Extension fields built using professional ABAP development tools
  • Custom logic (BAdIs and BDEF extensions) with advanced editor capabilities
  • RAP Business Objects (full-fledge RESTful ABAP applications)
  • CDS views and OData services with full development tooling
  • Analytical queries and custom analytical content

This level of extensibility is used when EHS implementations require more complex data models, multi-step validations, or custom processes beyond the key user scope.

2.3 Side-by-Side Extensibility

When requirements cannot be fulfilled within the S/4HANA Cloud stack, SAP BTP provides a powerful platform for building complementary applications:

  • SAP Build Apps (no-code mobile and web apps)
  • SAP Build Process Automation (workflows and automations)
  • SAP Build Work Zone (custom dashboard and portals)
  • SAP Build Code / CAP (cloud-native pro-code development, Node.js/Java)
  • ABAP Environment on BTP (Steampunk) for ABAP Cloud side-by-side extensions

Side-by-side extensibility is particularly relevant for EHS when:

  • complex mobile solutions are required (e.g. hazard observations, audits)
  • workflow automation or robotic processing is desired
  • large-scale integration scenarios (e.g., IoT sensors, safety systems) are needed
  • custom employee or contractor portals must be built

Although side-by-side extensibility plays an important role in the overall SAP extensibility strategy, we will not dive deeper into BTP-based extensions in this blog post. Our objective is to demonstrate what can be achieved directly within the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, using standard in-app extensibility options that remain fully aligned with SAPâ€™s clean-core principles. Based on our project experience, most EHS related enhancements such as custom fields, logic, reporting extensions, and form adaptations can be delivered efficiently using Key User or Developer Extensibility (on-stack). For this reason, the upcoming chapters focus exclusively on in-app, upgrade-safe extensibility scenarios that can be implemented without additional BTP architecture.

2.4 BAdIs in the Public Cloud (Key User vs. Developer Access)

Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) are predefined extension points provided by SAP that allow injecting custom logic while staying upgrade safe. You can explore the available BAdIs for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud here: Business Add-Ins | SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) | SAP Business Accelerator Hub

There are two categories in S/4HANA Public Cloud:

Key User BAdIs

  • Implemented through the Custom Logic SAP Fiori app
  • Available only for selected business contexts
  • Designed for simple enhancements such as: Validation rules, Derivation of field values, Basic calculations

Developer BAdIs

  • Implemented using ABAP Development Tools (ADT) in SAP BTP ABAP Environment or Embedded Steampunk
  • Allow more complex coding scenarios
  • Enable interaction with APIs, CDS views, RAP BOs and advanced data handling

In EHS specifically, SAP provides a growing set of BAdIs â€“ particularly in Incident Management and Emissions Management â€“ which are essential for country specific reporting, custom form generation, or regulatory compliance.

The following list provides an overview of the EHS-specific BAdIs that are currently available in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Incident Management

  • BAdI: Change of Field Values in BG (Berufsgenossenschaft) Incident Report (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Incident Basic Information (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Custom Field Incident Data (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Involved Person Data (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Incident Root Data (Key User)

Risk Management

  • (No BAdIs available for Risk Management in Public Cloud yet)

Emissions Management

  • BAdI: Field Control for Extension of Amount Root (Key User)
  • BAdI: Check Amounts State and Perform Subsequent Actions (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Generation of Export Files (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Compliance Requirement Import from XLSX (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Automatic Data Collection Import (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Automatic Data Collection Import from XLSX BAdI (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Automatic Data Collection XLSX Parser BAdI (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Field Control for Extension of Data Collection Root (Key User)

As the overview shows, the currently available BAdIs for EHS in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud are primarily focused on Key User Extensibility, especially within Incident Management and Emissions Management. While Developer Extensibility via ABAP Cloud provides a more advanced pro-code extension model, the current EHS-specific enhancement points are mostly delivered as in-app, low-code BAdIs to ensure upgrade stability and full alignment with SAPâ€™s clean core principles.

This corresponds closely with our experience from project implementations: Most EHS extension requirements can be delivered efficiently using in-app, Key User Extensibility tools such as Custom Fields, Custom Logic, UI Adaptation, and CDS View extensions without requiring developer access.

 

3. Practical Extensibility Scenarios in EHS

In chapter 2, we explored the extensibility options available in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and outlined which of these options are most relevant for EHS implementations. As highlighted, the majority of extensibility points currently exposed in the EHS area (especially within Incident Management and Emissions Management) are implemented using Key User Extensibility, including custom fields, UI adaptation, form template configuration, and Custom Logic BAdIs.

Because of this, this chapter focuses exclusively on Key User Extensibility in practice, demonstrating how customers can solve real-world EHS requirements entirely within the Public Cloud without requiring developer extensibility or SAP BTP side-by-side extensions.

Drawing from our project experience, we selected two scenarios that reflect common customer requirements:

  1. Adding custom attributes to the Incident Management process
  2. Generating a country-specific incident report, using custom form templates and multiple BAdIs

Both scenarios illustrate how far customers can go using the extensibility tools embedded in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, while fully adhering to the clean-core principle.

3.1 Example 1 - Introducing a Custom Attribute for Incident Records

Extensibility Type:

  • Key User Extensibility

Tools & Apps Used:

  • Custom Fields App (SAP Fiori App)
  • UI Adaptation (SAP Fiori Settings)

3.1.1 Business Requirement

Many organizations require an additional field â€œBusiness Unitâ€ to be captured as part of incident documentation to meet internal reporting needs, support organizational analysis, or fulfill local compliance requirements. Since this information is not available in the standard SAP EHS Public Cloud data model, customers often need to introduce it as a custom field.

Typically, the Business Unit may be required in multiple stages of the Incident Management process, such as:

  • Incident Creation
  • Incident Processing
  • Reporting and Analytics Dashboards

In our case, the Business Unit field was only added to the Incident Processing step, primarily for simplicity and to demonstrate the extensibility approach in clear and focused manner. However, this field can be added to additional UIs and process steps as needed, depending on the customerâ€™s specific requirements, organizational structure, or compliance obligations.

3.1.2 Step-by-Step Implementation

Create New Custom Field

In this step a custom field for the Incident Management will be created using the â€œCustom Fieldsâ€ Fiori App. You can follow the steps below to create a custom field:

1. Navigate to the â€œCustom Fieldsâ€ app from the Fiori Launchpad.

2. Click â€œCreateâ€.

3. Enter the following details:

  • Business Context: Select the relevant context (e.g. EHHSS_INC_BINFA).
  • Label: Provide a meaningful name (Business Unit). Identifier & Tooltip will be filled automatically.
  • Type: Choose from options like Text, Number, Date, etc.
  • Length: Define the size of the field if applicable.

Create New Field

After the required details have been filled, select Create and Edit.

4. Enable the fields for the relevant applications.

The fields of the tabs User Interfaces, Analytics and APIs will be enabled by default. These tabs are required to support user interactions, reporting as well as integrations for the recently added custom field (Business Unit).

Field Enablement

If the new field should appear in generated documents such as PDFs or reports, you need to enable the required Form Templates. In our scenario, two Form Templates were activated as shown below.

Enabled Form Templates

Note: The YY1_WHS_FORM10 Template is a custom Form Template. The creation of this Form Template will be shown in chapter 3.2.

5. Save and publish the custom field to make it available in the system.

 

Assign custom field to Fiori app

Custom fields created by using the â€œCustom Fieldsâ€ Fiori app can be assigned to the relevant Fiori applications based on the selected business context. Follow these steps to add the field:

1. Open the â€œManage Incidentâ€ Fiori app & click on any incident.

2. Click on your profile & choose â€œAdapt UIâ€

Navigate to "Adapt UI"

 3. Once Adapt UI is activated, you can start customizing the page layout and add the recently created custom field to the relevant sections. By selecting â€œCustomizeâ€ > â€œShow Customizable Areasâ€ as shown below, you will be able to insert the new custom field â€œBusiness Unitâ€ into the desired section of the Fiori App.

Navigate to "Show Customizable Areas"

 4. Select the Customizable Area that should be changed.

Select Customizable Area

 5. Select the element as shown below & click on â€œCustomize UIBBâ€.

Select "Customize UIBB"

 6. To add the new field, select â€œElementâ€ > â€œAdd Elementâ€.

Add Element

 7. Select the recently created field YY1_BUSINESSUNIT_IBN and select â€œOKâ€.

Select field YY1_BUSINESSUNIT_IBN

 

In the below shown illustration you can see an example, after the Business Unit was added to the UI.

Field Business Unit added to UI

 8. Save the UI adaptation for this page.  

 

3.2 Example 2 - Generating a Country-Specific Incident Report

Extensibility Type:

  • Key User Extensibility

Tools & Apps Used:

  • Adobe Lifecycle Designer (External Tool)
  • Maintain Form Template App (SAP Fiori App)
  • Custom Logic App (SAP Fiori App)
  • CBC Configuration (SAP Public Cloud) / or if no access exists Implementation Activities (SAP Fiori App)

3.2.1 Business Requirement

In many EHS implementations, customers need to generate country-specific incident reports that comply with national legal requirements. These reports often require a combination of standard fields, people related information, and custom fields that are not provided in the SAP EHS Public Cloud standard forms. For example, organizations operating in Australia may be required to submit the WHS Form 10, a mandatory workplace health and safety report documenting incidents, injuries, or hazards in accordance with the Australian Work Health and Safety (WHS) Regulations (made-up). To support this requirement, a custom Adobe form template must be created and populated with incident data, including custom fields. This requires implementing the relevant Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) to retrieve, map, and supply the correct incident information into the custom form.

The report must include:

  • Basic incident details
  • Person and involvement information
  • Custom fields required for the local legislative format

3.2.2 Step-by-Step Implementation

Develop a Custom Form in Adobe Lifecycle Designer

A custom form template needs to be created to meet the specific requirements of the report. The form should include all necessary fields. To showcase this example, we created the form template YY1_WHS_FORM10 in Adobe Lifecycle Designer and saved it as an xdp file.

Form Template Creation in Adobe Lifecycle Designer

 

Upload Custom Form in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

Once the custom form template is created in Adobe Lifecycle Designer, the next step is to upload it to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud by using the â€œMaintain Form Templateâ€ app.

1. Open the â€œMaintain Form Templateâ€ app in your SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system.

2. Navigate to the â€œCustom Templateâ€ tab.

3. Click â€œNewâ€ to create a new entry.

4. Enter a Form Template Name of your choice (for example â€œYY1_WHS_FORM10â€ including the prefix â€œYY1_â€ for custom forms).

5. Upload the form file that you created in Adobe Lifecycle Designer.

6. Select the Data Source Name as â€œEHSS_FDP_INCIDENT_SRVâ€.

The illustration below shows how the form setup was done in our scenario.

Form Setup (1)

Form Setup (2)

 

Assign Custom Fields & Custom Logic to the form

In this step we assign the created custom fields & logic to the form (shown in the previous step). This is achieved by using the â€œCustom Logicâ€ app in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, where you can leverage the available Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) provided by the system. To retrieve the required information in the form, you can implement the following BAdIs:

  • BADI_EHHSS_INC_BASIC_INFO
  • BADI_EHHSS_INC_INVOLVED_PERS
  • BADI_EHHSS_INC_ROOT

1. Click â€œCreateâ€ to start a new implementation.

2. Select one of the mentioned BAdIs above and proceed to â€œStep 2â€ (if no filters are needed jump over to step 3 and enter an Implementation Description).

3. Create and publish the Implementation.

4. Navigate to the created Implementation.

Created Implementations

 5. Select â€œCode Editorâ€ and write ABAP logic using released APIs and CDS views.

Open Code Editor

The below shown BAdI implementation YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_BASIC_INFO retrieves incident basic information from the CDS View I_IncidentBasicInfo and populates the INCIDENTBASICINFO structure, so that key fields such as the Creation Date Time or Business Unit (which was previously created as a custom field in chapter 3.1) are available in the custom form.

YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_BASIC_INFO

Perform the same steps for the other required BadIs.

BAdI YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_INVOLVED_PE retrieves involved person details, such as Personâ€™s Full Name, from the CDS View I_IncidentInvolvedPerson which makes it available in the custom form.

YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_INVOLVED_PE

BAdI YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_ROOT retrieves root-level incident data such as CreationDateTime from the CDS View I_Incident and makes these fields available for the custom form.

YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_ROOT

Note: BAdIs are essential because they supply data for custom and standard fields in the form. Without these implementations, the fields would remain empty, as the standard logic does not retrieve the required CDS view information.

6. Click â€œPublishâ€ to implement.

 

Functional Configuration (Assign Form to regulation)

Uploading the Adobe form just makes the template available in the system. To actually use it in the EHS process, you need to specify the form and assign it to the correct form group and regulation. This ensures the form is linked to the appropriate compliance context and can be selected when generating reports.

This can be achieved by performing the mentioned steps below performed in the SAP Central Business Configuration (or â€Implementation Activitiesâ€ app).

1. Specify form: Select one of the mentioned apps above and navigate to SAP Business Configuration > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety > Specify Forms

Each form entry shows key technical attributes:

  • Form Name & Form Title : Represents the form to be specified (In our scenario: WHS).
  • Form Type: Indicates the technology used for the form. In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, this is typically â€œSAP Interactive Formâ€, which refers to Adobe-based forms used for output and reporting.
  • Form Controller: Controls the rendering and behavior of the form in SAP (In our scenario: CL_EHFND_FW_ADS_OM_FORM_CTRL).
  • Data Provider: Supplies the data from the EHS process to the form (In our scenario: CL_EHHSS_AIF_INCIDENT_DPROV).
  • Form Object Name: Identifies the form template used for output. This should match the custom form you uploaded earlier in the â€œMaintain Form Templateâ€ app (In our scenario: YY1_WHS_FORM10).

Specify Form

 2. Assign Form to the Form Group: Select one of the mentioned apps above and navigate to SAP Business Configuration  > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety > Specify Form Groups and Assign Forms

Assign Form to Form Group (1)

After defining the form groups, the next step is to assign the relevant specified forms to these groups. This can be performed on the second level of the selected form group and ensures that the custom or standard forms are correctly linked to the appropriate reporting or regulatory context.

Assign Form to Form Group (2)

 3. Specify Regulations & assign Regulation to Incidents: Select one of the mentioned apps above and navigate to SAP Business Configuration > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety >  Specify Regulations.

Specify Regulations & Assign Regulation to Incidents (1)

After specifying the regulation (e.g., WHS), the next step is to assign it to the relevant incident categories. This ensures that when users select a regulation in the Incident process, the correct forms from the assigned form group become available for reporting.

Specify Regulations & Assign Regulation to Incidents (2)

 4. Assign the Forms to Regulations: Finally, link the forms to the corresponding regulation. This step ensures that when a regulation (e.g., WHS) is selected in the Incident process, the correct form becomes available for reporting.

Therefore, open the SAP Central Business Configuration > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety > Assign Forms to Regulations.

Assign Forms to Regulations

 

Generating the Report

Once the configuration is complete, you can generate the report directly from the â€œManage Incidentâ€ app.

1. Open the â€œManage Incidentâ€ app

2. Select any Incident which has the status  â€œIn Processâ€.

3. Click on â€œRegulationsâ€, choose â€œWHSâ€, then click â€œOKâ€ andâ€ Saveâ€.

Generate Report (1)

After selecting the WHS regulation, the system makes the corresponding report option available under the â€œReportsâ€ tab.

4. Navigate to the â€œReportsâ€ tab.

5. Select the WHS Report from the list.

6. Click â€œGenerateâ€ to create the report.

Generate Report (2)

Once you click â€œGenerateâ€ for the selected Report Type, the WHS report is created and appears in the list as a downloadable PDF.

Generate Report (3)

The final output reflects all required incident details, including custom and standard fields, in the WHS Form 10 format.

Output

 

4. Summary & Lessons Learned

Extensibility plays a critical role in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud implementations for Environment, Health, and Safety (EHS). As demonstrated throughout this blog post, even highly regulated processes such as incident reporting or country-specific compliance documentation can be effectively supported using SAPâ€™s clean-core extensibility framework.

Drawing from our project experience and the two practical use cases presented, this chapter summarizes the key takeaways and highlights the most important lessons learned when implementing extensibility in EHS Public Cloud.

4.1 Key Takeaways

Clean-Core Extensibility Is Not a Limitation â€“ It is a Design Principle

The SAP Public Cloud model enforces strict boundaries around what can be extended. Rather than restricting customers, these boundaries ensure:

  • Long-term upgrade protection
  • Predictable lifecycle behavior
  • Lower maintenance effort
  • Full SAP supportability

All enhancements must therefore rely on SAP-released extension points.

Most EHS Requirements Can Be Solved with Key User Extensibility

A major insight from our implementations is that the majority of EHS use cases do not require developer extensibility or side-by-side applications.

Key User tools already cover:

  • Custom data fields
  • UI adaptations
  • PDF report adjustments
  • BAdI logic

Both examples in this blog were fully implemented using Key User Extensibility only.

BAdIs Are the Backbone of EHS Extensibility

SAP delivers a growing catalogue of EHS specific BAdIs in the Public Cloud, particularly for:

  • Incident Management
  • Emissions Management

Key lessons:

  • Each BAdI is designed for a very specific business context.
  • You often need to use several BAdIs together to populate a report for a form.
  • They enable retrieving structured data via released CDS Views and APIs.
  • Clean and modular implementations significantly improve maintainability.

Custom Forms Require a Structured Approach

Regulatory reports require a combination of:

  • A form template (Adobe)
  • Custom fields
  • BAdI logic
  • CBC configuration

The lesson: Form extensibility is not only a technical activity â€“ it is a cross-functional exercise involving business, logic, and configuration layers.

Configuration in SAP Central Business Configuration (CBC) / Implementation Activities is Essential

EHS reporting relies heavily on CBC / Implementation Activities, especially when assigning:

  • Forms > form groups
  • Form groups > regulations
  • Regulations > incident categories

A common project challenge: Without correct CBC (or Implementation Activities) configuration, even perfectly implemented forms and BAdIs will not appear in the UI.

End-to-End Testing Is Crucial

Because EHS extensions span UI, logic, reporting and configuration layers, testing must always validate the entire lifecycle:

  • Incident creation > processing > regulation selection > report generation

This avoids fragmented testing and ensures that all extension layers work together seamlessly.

4.2 Lessons Learned

Start With the Simplest Possible Extension Option

Always begin with Key User tools before considering Developer Extensibility or SAP BTP. Public Cloud projects succeed when complexity is added only where absolutely necessary.

Choose BAdIs Wisely â€“ Donâ€™t Over-Engineer

Each BAdI serves a narrow purpose. Trying to force a single BAdI to solve multiple needs often causes issues later. Modular, purpose-aligned implementations are easier to maintain and debug.

Document Custom Logic and Configuration Thoroughly

Because Public Cloud enforces strict structure, even small enhancements should be:

  • Named consistently (YY1_*)
  • Documented cleanly (purpose, input, output)
  • Readable for team members who join the project later.

Well-documented extensions also reduce future rework during audits or regulatory updates.

Maintain a Strong Governance Around Extensibility

Typical governance measures include:

  • Reviewing whether a need truly requires an extension
  • Maintaining a central register of custom fields and BAdIs
  • Ensuring no duplicate fields are created
  • Enforcing naming conventions

This prevents uncontrolled growth of extensions over time.

Engage Business Users Early in the Design Process

EHS professionals often know exactly how regulations should be represented. Early involvement helps:

  • Avoid unnecessary extensions
  • Validate report layouts
  • Confirm the accuracy of populated data
  • Ensure usability in real operational scenarios

Plan for Future Regulatory Requirements

EHS compliance evolves frequently. When building extensions, always think ahead:

  • Could this field or form be reused for another regulation?
  • Can we structure the logic to accommodate more categories in the future?
  • Are we using modular BAdI implementations that can scale?

This significantly reduces technical dept.

4.3 Best Practices

To close this chapter, here is a consolidated best-practice checklist:

  • Use SAP-released extension points only (clean core).
  • Prefer Key User Extensibility for EHS whenever possible.
  • Keep BAdI implementations modular and business-context specific.
  • Use functional naming conventions for fields, forms, and BAdIs.
  • Perform end-to-end lifecycle testing (UI > logic > form > CBC).
  • Document every extension early, including purpose and data sources.
  • Reuse released CDS Views and APIs â€“ never rely on unreleased objects.
  • Involve business users early to ensure regulatory accuracy.
  • Build form templates in a future-proof, scalable structure.
  • Maintain strong governance to avoid unnecessary or duplicate extensions.

4.4 Final Remark

Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is not about pushing technical boundaries. It is about using the right tools to deliver business value while protecting system integrity. With a structured approach, as illustrated in both examples, customers can achieve regulatory compliance, process optimization, and system flexibility without compromising the clean-core principles that define the Public Cloud.

 

 

5. Engage with Us

To follow the series, make sure to subscribe to the SAP EHS Public Cloud blog tag.

We welcome your thoughts and feedback in the comments!
